reviews.review_msg: His accent gets kind of heavy and it becomes hard to understand when he starts talking really fast along with him going on tangents irrelevant to the lecture. The amount of work and reading (about 100 pages per week) required for simply 4% journals is a lot. That along with the midterm where the grading is very strict. Super nice but hard teacher

I took several upper-division classes with Kawasaki including POL 381, and he is arguably one of the best profs: I was able to learn a lot through his knowledgeable lectures and journal assignments. Couldn't agree more with the review written in 2017, that is, "the stuff you learn is extremely practical". He is also caring.

The textbook is extremely biased for Japan. The lecture was meaningless to sit there and listen but gotta attend for the attendance. He is deterministic in interpreting political matters, rather than being more objective or neutral. I think he sometimes confuses himself in distinguishing Realism, Constructivism and Liberalism.

The textbook is worthless, he says so himself... At least I think that's what he said. Most of the lecture's were completely unintelligible. As far as writing a final paper goes, you better be able to read Japanese, there were nearly NO English language sources for information. If you need to ask him a question... good luck getting an answer.
A very witty, funny prof. I really enjoyed his Japanese politics class. Highly recommended.
Super easy. Got an a for no effort..haha....attendance mark a bonus (basically just sleep through the class)..final exam is hilariously easy
very difficult course.  had to write a long long essay at the end.  nice guy.  u can ask him question and he'll answer u but u'll never understand what he said.
He's not good at teaching. Accent difficult to understand. (I don't usually pick on people's accent but his is really thick) The final is easy though.
